title: Citi Supports Empowering Women in Latin America
summary: Quito, Ecuador - The second conference on "Empowering Women in Latin America," organized by the Citi Foundation and Junior Achievement, brought more than 20 representatives from 12 Latin American and Caribbean countries - Argentina, El Salvador, Guatemala, Paraguay, Dominican Republic, Colombia, Honduras, Costa Rica, Trinidad & Tobago, Paraguay, Panama and the United States - to Quito in mid-October.
tag-1: Citi Supports Empowering Women in Latin America
tag-2: Quito, Ecuador – The second conference on "Empowering Women in Latin America," organized by the Citi Foundation and Junior Achievement, brought more than 20 representatives from 12 Latin American and Caribbean countries – Argentina, El Salvador, Guatemala, Paraguay, Dominican Republic, Colombia, Honduras, Costa Rica, Trinidad & Tobago, Paraguay, Panama and the United States – to Quito in mid-October.
tag-3: Panelists analyzed the challenges faced by women in vulnerable situations and presented best practices in countries participating in the regional Women's Entrepreneurs Project, sponsored by the Citi Foundation and coordinated by Junior Achievement.
tag-4: The Citi Foundation first launched the Women's Entrepreneurs Project in Paraguay in collaboration with Fundación Paraguaya in 2006. To date, the program has trained more than 4,600 women across the region and helped more than 60 percent of them obtain access to credit for starting or improving their own businesses, with the goal of increasing their income and improving the quality of life of their families and communities.
tag-5: In 2013, project participants in Ecuador and the Dominican Republic will also have the opportunity to start their own businesses via micro-franchises, earning a stable income by distributing and commercializing basic goods in collaboration with companies committed to improving the quality of life of low-income families.
tag-6: At the conference, "the Junior Achievement and Citi representatives set consistent goals and implementation plans; defined new strategies for improving implementation and consolidating and expanding the program; and identified opportunities for working together to forge new partnerships," said Luis Salazar, Executive Director of Junior Achievement Ecuador.
tag-7: The event closed with a forum at the Latin American School of Social Sciences (FLACSO) in which prominent women labor leaders and public and regional officials analyzed the evolution of women's role in the current economy and opportunities for their incorporation into the labor market in innovative and sustainable ways.
tag-8: Diana Torres, General Manager of Citi Ecuador, described the forum as extremely useful for participants. "It created a space for dialogue about current challenges in promoting gender equality and women's empowerment, taking into account such issues as increased female participation in the labor market in the last decade." She added, "such factors have given women a clearer vision of their role in the corporate world and their contributions to the country's productive development."
tag-9: Citi Citi, the leading global bank, has approximately 200 million customer accounts and does business in more than 160 countries and jurisdictions. Citi provides consumers, corporations, governments and institutions with a broad range of financial products and services, including consumer banking and credit, corporate and investment banking, securities brokerage, transaction services, and wealth management.

tag-11: Junior Achievement Junior Achievement Worldwide is a nonprofit organization that benefits more than 10 million students annually through 124 offices around the world. Junior Achievement was founded in 1919 and its mission since then has been business education by bringing private companies into the classroom.
